ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Before every class, there were prerecorded videos by Professor Hall that correspond to the textbook reading. Then, there is a live class with your section professor who goes over the material and does practice problems.

The classes consisted both of lectures (involving the professor solving problems and explaining concepts) and breakout rooms where we worked on problems and worksheets with a few other students. Because the class was small, it was easy to ask questions and get responses from the professor.
Pre-recorded videos to watch before every class; live, not-recorded Zoom style seminar for class. Live, not-recorded office hours for both my professor and peer tutors.
Recorded videos, readings and live virtual class.
Recorded videos
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Lecture videos recorded by course director
virtual section
We also had live class as well that went over what we learned in the recorded lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to think about and solve calculus problems in multidimensional spaces.

Aside from the specific content of the course, which can be found in the syllabus or in the textbook, one skill that I definitely developed through the problem sets was making 3D drawings. Although it was difficult for me and often took multiple attempts, I definitely got better as the semester went on.

It's a fast-paced and thorough coverage of all things multivariable calculus: LaGrange multipliers, Divergence Theorem, finding extrema of functions, etc. I do recommend it though! I found myself using the resources (ie office hours both for my professor and multiple peer tutors) which both quicked the speed at which I completed problem sets and the depth to which I understood the material. I have a much stronger grasp on 3D space and how functions may work in it.

I gained higher-order and critical thinking skills by taking this course. I expanded my knowledge of math and calculus far beyond what I have learned in high school. I am now able to solve problems of much greater difficulty and that require a much higher level of critical thinking.
I learned about the calculus of multivariate functions and, towards the end, their applications in areas like astrophysics and economics.
logical skills, enhanced my math knowledge
Multivariable calculus
I learned the fundamentals of multivariable calculus and refined my math skills, as well as getting much better at working under time pressure
problem solving, how to apply the right equations to solve a word problem
I learned about how to differentiate, integrate, and overall just deal with multi-variable functions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Class was very well organized and very thorough. Problems sets were very comprehensive and ensured you really understood the material. 
Weaknesses: The problem sets were very long and some problems just felt like a waste of time. It was also annoying when there were mistakes in them. Breakout rooms during live class was also very awkward.

Professor Uyanik was a terrific instructor. He explained concepts clearly, was patient with student questions, and always gave helpful answers. He was also always enthusiastic and energetic. The only potential weakness I can think of is that a number of the problems discussed in class were exactly the same as those in the textbook. This is a little bit of a double-edged sword; while it reinforced the concepts, it sometimes was a little repetitive. It was also frustrating that problem sets frequently had corrections made in the middle of the week, as I had already done them some of the time and thus had to redo my work. But that is understandable.

Strengths: it's so hard to do poorly if you reach out when you are struggling! I mean this. There are so many peer tutors and the professors are all willing to meet during office hours (or schedule another appointment) if you find yourself not understanding something. I really enjoyed feeling like I always had a solid support system. The videos were always uploaded early, along with problem sets, so I enjoyed the promptness of those. I did find myself struggling at some times to complete the pre-class quizzes on time because it's a lot of constant work, but the videos are very well made.
Weaknesses: it was really hard sometimes to reconcile the idea that I was in a huge class (lots of sections!) and also in my specific section. I felt a little shut-away from all the other MATH 120 students except during peer tutor office hours, where people from various classes would congregate. Again, I occasionally found myself struggling to make the pre-class quiz deadlines since it's such a constant (but small) workflow.

The strengths of this course were the resources available to help the students understand and master concepts and succeed in the class. The instructor and the course director were always available to talk to or email regarding unclear directions to assignments or ways to improve in the course. There were review sessions, peer tutor office hours, and supplemental resources that helped me understand difficult concepts that I struggled with understanding at first. The weakness of this course was the fast speed at which material was covered, which at times, made it difficult to truly understand concepts that were taught. More time could be allocated to difficult topics while less time could allocated to less difficult topics to help with the struggles I have had with the speed at which the material was covered at.

The breakout sessions were boring and often nervewracking, as usually no one spoke and it was very awkward. The problem sets were fine and could be done especially if you had help from another student, but if you didn't know anybody else in the class it was hard to get help unless you went to the peer tutors (which is scary). The second and third midterms were not really like the practice midterms in my opinion and they should have been more like the first. I loved the final project, and I hope they continue to implement the project even after virtual learning is done.

Strengths: the course was well structured and the material was straightforward.

Weaknesses: it was hard to get to know Professor Uyanik due to the online format.

Strengths: very organized, clear textbook and lectures, dedicated teaching staff, lots of support/office hours
Weaknesses: given both the virtual and live lectures, it felt like there could be a lot of repetition of the same topic.  I often felt like I was just doing busywork to get through reading the book, watching the videos, and going to live lecture.

The recorded lectures were very informative and helpful. Actual class felt slightly repetitive, but helped reinforce the ideas. The exams were fair but the graders are very nit-picky, and the anonymity of graders encourages this.
It is very straightforward

Strengths: The material was very clear and well presented in the the pre-recorded lectures. There were many opportunities to get help on things I didn't understand. I also thought the material presented was pretty cool.

Weaknesses: The live sessions weren't super engaging.

strengths: the pace of the class is appropriate
weaknesses: how much you learn in class depends on which prof you get

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Prerecorded videos from Professor Hall were a great alternative to reading the textbook.
Weaknesses: Breakout rooms were awkward and often not conducive to collaboration among students.

I thought that the lecturing worked very well, as we could see Professor Uyanik's screen and his work. I also think that we were able to be engaged in class in asking questions and responding to his questions. I also enjoyed the breakout sessions where we worked in groups, although there was often not much discussion in those groups (although this might be the same dynamic even if in-person). If I have one suggestion, it might be to have more anonymous polls, so that students can participate more without being afraid of answering incorrectly. There were a number of them, particularly towards the end of the course, but more could be utilized.

The pre-recorded lectures are helpful! I really like how well the videos are made, even if my professor reviewed many of the same concepts in class. I also appreciated how we were put into breakout rooms (encouraged to turn video and audio on) to do worksheet problems. I think the biggest con of COVID-era learning is that it's sometimes a little hard to find all the other people who are also taking MATH 120. I feel like I could've met a lot of other math-loving (or math-struggling) people if there was more unity across sections.

The live virtual lectures succeeded. The concepts were taught by the instructor in a way that was both engaging and helpful to my learning. The breakout rooms during class time helped me communicate with peers and work through problems assigned by the instructor. The pre-class recorded videos by the course director were also very helpful in the understanding of concepts in this course. More poll questions could be assigned during the live virtual lectures to facilitate more engagement from all students in the class.

The fact that the last midterm for this course (that has a majority first-year population) was two days before move-out during a pandemic is disgraceful. It put so much pressure on 18 year olds to decide whether to prioritize their housing situations and moving out or the midterm. The online midterms are already stressful enough because of the strange format and being required to keep your audio on, but forcing first-years to take an important exam while they are coming to terms with the end of their first real college experience is upsetting to say the least.
The prerecorded videos were clear and easy to follow, but the live lecture felt a bit repetitive afterwards as we mostly covered the same material.

I did not really like having both recorded and live full-length lectures.  It felt like I was doing the same thing over again 3 times for one topic, and watching the videos in addition to reading the textbook and going to class took up a lot of time.
The recorded lecture videos by Prof. Hall were very helpful. Class could have been more engaging.

I thought learning via pre-recorded lectures was really effective because I could pause and re-watch difficult bits that I didn't understand at first. Class participation was pretty hard in the zoom lecture format because it felt kinda awkward, but there was nothing really you can do about that. I liked that the live sessions used breakout-rooms to solve example problems, I thought that was the most useful part of the class. The lecture before the breakout-rooms sometimes was a bit repetitive of the pre-recorded lectures and was a bit boring because of it.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes but only if you need it and at least enjoy calculus a little bit. It's very application based so you'll be spending a lot of time doing problems. Outside of class, I found myself spending around 10 hours a week on average.

Many people who take this course do so because it is a pre-requisite either for their major or for a course they wish to take. To that end, I would certainly not not recommend the course. It is certainly challenging--even for someone who has taken a high school course on the material--but the concepts that are covered are pretty important and fundamental. So for someone who wishes to take further mathematics or courses which require a solid mathematical foundation, I would certainly recommend it. But if someone simply wishes to obtain a QR credit, there are probably easier courses with lower workloads that people can take.

Yes, do take it! Some people will say it's really fast-paced and difficult, but so long as you go to peer tutor/instructor office hours, you will be just fine. It's a good kind of intellectual stretch. I think it helps if you have some familiarity with multivariable calc before entering, but I'd say that a good number of people who take this course don't have that. Also, the frequency of the exams (3 midterms!) may seem daunting, but I found studying for each to be manageable, given the resources they provide. If you're looking for a review on Caglar, I 100% recommend: super clear lecturer, very patient explainer, and all-around very likable and technologically-adept (go screen-sharing except when he occasionally forgets, you should just remind him if that ever happens).

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The intellectual challenge of this course was definitely greater than any other course I have taken during my first semester at Yale. However, there are many resources to help students succeed, and reaching out for help on difficult concepts or questions on lecture material is always an option, and a great skill to have in this course.
Not really unless it is required for your major.
I would recommend this course only they need it for their major / future career interests.
Yes, it is a clear overview of the basics of multivariable calculus.  Throughout the course, I was consistently impressed with how well-organized and clear it was.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to refine their mathematics or needs to take this course. But be warned it is not a course to take "for fun". It is difficult, but with proper preparation and attendance, a good grade should not be out of reach. The professors, especially the course director Prof. Hall, are very helpful and answer questions and care greatly about teaching.
I would recommend it if you are confident about your math background and it is a requirement for a potential major.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in math. You kinda have to take it if you want to take upper level math courses, and I thought the material was well taught and the expectations of the class were reasonable.
